discussion.content:
AF is the right answer anyday.
USER_TABLE - dictionary view which has list of tables owned by the user
ALL_TABLE - dictionary view which has list of tables owned by the user + tables which user has grants for.
DBA_TABLE - All tables in database(but you should have dba privelege to see them)

comments.content: F is incorrect because if i have only my owntables and no access to others. i dont need ANY TABLE privileges to see my own table in all tables
granting select any table to my user did not allow him to query dba_tables

discussion.content:
AD , the right answers.

The data dictionary views that begin with DBA_ are restricted. These views can be accessed only by users with the SELECT_ANY_TABLE privilege. This privilege is assigned to the DBA role when the system is initially installed.

https://docs.oracle.com/cd/A57673_01/DOC/server/doc/SRF73/ch2a.htm

Selected Answer: AF
if you don't have dba role then you will get message that DBA_TABLES doesn't exist.
DBA_TABLES is a data dictionary view

I tried D and it doesn't work for me!!!!
But its probably A. idk about the 2nd option

AD
to view dba_table should have privilege.

Selected Answer: AF
i am for AF

AD.

Tried on ORA 19. 
GRANT SELECT ANY_TABLE to gives access to DBA_TABLES
F is incorrect because querying ALL_TABLES you can always do but only see those tables you have the rights to view, which would be a subset of DBA_TABLES

Selected Answer: AF
AF
cannot grant dba_tables privilege

Don't get USER_TABLE and ALL_TABLE views confused.
A) USER_TABLES displays all tables owned by the current user. (True)
E) ALL_TABLES displays all tables owned by the current user. (False) 
The ALL_TABLES view contains description of tables accessible to the user.

choices.A: USER_TABLES displays all tables owned by the current user.
choices.E: ALL_TABLES displays all tables owned by the current user.
choices.F: You must have ANY TABLE system privileges, or be granted object privileges on the table, to view a table in ALL_TABLES.
choices.C: All users can query DBA_TABLES successfully.
choices.B: You must have ANY TABLE system privileges, or be granted object privileges on the table, to view a table in USER_TABLES.
choices.D: You must have ANY TABLE system privileges, or be granted object privileges on the table, to view a table in DBA_TABLES.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about *_TABLES views? (Choose two.)
Which four statements are true regarding primary and foreign key constraints and the effect they can have on table data? (Choose four.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADFG
A, D, F and G are correct.

choices.C: The foreign key columns and parent table primary key columns must have the same names.
choices.D: A table can have only one primary key but multiple foreign keys.
choices.G: It is possible for child rows that have a foreign key to be deleted automatically from the child table at the time the parent row is deleted.
choices.A: Primary key and foreign key constraints can be defined at both the column and table level.
choices.F: It is possible for child rows that have a foreign key to remain in the child table at the time the parent row is deleted.
choices.B: A table can have only one primary key and one foreign key.
choices.E: Only the primary key can be defined at the column and table level.

choices.D: You have the UNLIMITED TABLESPACE privilege or sufficient quota for the tablespace to contain the index.
choices.E: You have either the INDEX privilege on the table or the CREATE ANY INDEX privilege.
choices.A: You must have the UNLIMITED TABLESPACE privilege.
choices.C: You must have the CREATE ANY INDEX privilege.
choices.B: You must have either the SELECT privilege on the table or the SELECT ANY TABLE privilege.

questions.question_text: Which two are true to create an index in your own schema for a table owned by another schema? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
o create an index on a table in another schema in your own schema, you must either own the table or have been granted the INDEX object privilege on that table, or possess the CREATE ANY INDEX system privilege
docs.oracle.com
. In our scenario the table isn’t owned by the user, so the user needs either the object privilege (GRANT INDEX ON table_name TO user) or the CREATE ANY INDEX privilege. Having either of those will satisfy the privilege requirement to create the index. (If the user already has CREATE ANY INDEX, that covers it; if not, the table’s owner can grant the INDEX privilege on that specific table.)

choices.A: Each row returned by the subquery can be inserted into only a single target table.
choices.D: It cannot have an ELSE clause.
choices.B: A single WHEN condition can be used for multiple INTO clauses.
choices.C: Each WHEN condition is tested for each row returned by the subquery.
choices.E: The total number of rows inserted is always equal to the number of rows returned by the subquery.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about conditional INSERT ALL? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B and C are correct.

choices.B: It can only be used for NUMBER data types.
choices.C: COUNT(DISTINCT inv_amt) returns the number of rows excluding rows containing duplicates and NULLs in the INV_AMT column.
choices.E: A SELECT statement using the COUNT function with a DISTINCT keyword cannot have a WHERE clause.
choices.A: COUNT(*) returns the number of rows in a table including duplicate rows and rows containing NULLs in any column.
choices.D: COUNT(inv_amt) returns the number of rows in a table including rows with NULL in the INV_AMT column

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about the COUNT function? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Group functions do not consider NULL values, except the COUNT(*)

Selected Answer: AC
A and C are correct.
